message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest celiac disease. The most appropriate next step in management of the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms is a gluten-free diet. Metronidazole therapy is used for bacterial infections. Avoiding milk products may help with lactose intolerance, but it won't address the underlying issue of celiac disease. Intravenous immunoglobulin therapy is used for autoimmune disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest celiac disease, which is treated with a gluten-free diet. Metronidazole therapy is used for bacterial infections, intravenous immunoglobulin therapy is used to treat immunodeficiencies, and avoiding milk products is a treatment for lactose intolerance, which is not the primary diagnosis in this case. A biopsy for confirmation of the diagnosis is suggested, but the patient is unwilling to undergo the procedure. Therefore, a gluten-free diet is the most appropriate next step in managing the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with celiac disease, including diarrhea, bloating, and abdominal discomfort, as well as a positive IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody test. A gluten-free diet is the most appropriate management for celiac disease. Metronidazole therapy is used for bacterial infections. Avoiding milk products is not specific to celiac disease. Intravenous immunoglobulin therapy is used for autoimmune disorders.

IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody is positive and a gluten-free diet is the most appropriate management for gastrointestinal symptoms associated with celiac disease. Metronidazole therapy is used to treat infections caused by anaerobic bacteria, but there is no indication of infection in this case. Avoiding milk products is not a solution for celiac disease. Intravenous immunoglobulin therapy is used to treat autoimmune disorders, but is not indicated for celiac disease.

Intravenous immunoglobulin therapy is used in autoimmune diseases, but celiac disease is not an autoimmune disease.
